description.description: A short description of the brand.

Job.description: Represents a job posting in the careers portal.

slug.description: A unique, URL-friendly identifier for the job.

division.description: The division or department for the job.

location.description: The physical location of the job.

brandId.description: The ID of the brand this job belongs to.

coverImageUrl.description: URL of the cover image for the job posting.

specialRequirementsHtml.description: Special or specific job requirements in HTML format.

updatedBy.description: UID of the user who last updated the job.

candidateName.description: Denormalized full name of the candidate.

jobId.description: The ID of the job being applied for.

jobPosition.description: Denormalized position title from the Job.

brandId.description: Denormalized brand ID from the Job.

brandName.description: Denormalized brand name from the Job.

jobType.description: Denormalized job type (fulltime, etc.) from the Job.

status.description: The current status of the application.

createdAt.description: Timestamp when the application draft was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp when the application was last updated.

submittedAt.description: Timestamp when the application was formally submitted.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to provide a secure and scalable foundation for the HRP Starter Kit application. It emphasizes authorization independence, clarity, and adherence to Firestore best practices.

The design leverages path-based ownership for user profiles, ensuring that only the user (or a super_admin) can access their data.  This is achieved by placing user documents at `/users/{userId}`. This structure inherently provides authorization independence; security rules can validate `request.auth.uid` against the `{userId}` path segment without needing to perform costly and brittle `get()` operations to check ownership.

The application requirements include a seeding process that creates initial user accounts with specific roles.  The `users/{userId}` collection stores user profiles (fullName, email, role, isActive, createdAt) and facilitates role-based access control. The `super_admin` role has read/write access to all collections, which is achieved in security rules by checking for the existence of a document in a dedicated `/roles_admin/{userId}` collection.

QAPs (Rules Are Not Filters): List operations are inherently safe due to the structure.  A regular user can only read their own document in `users/{userId}`, so listing the entire collection would return no documents (without super_admin privileges).  The super_admin role, indicated by membership in `/roles_admin/{userId}`, grants broad access and bypasses the filtering constraints imposed on other users.

Authorization Independence: Achieved by storing all necessary authorization information directly within the user document at `/users/{userId}` (specifically, the `role` field) and leveraging path-based ownership. The super admin role is checked for via existence of a document, avoiding document `get()` calls.
